head.title: Sept. 3-9; A Gigantic Gathering Of World Leaders

hedline.hl1: Sept. 3-9; A Gigantic Gathering Of World Leaders

block.p: Secretary General Kofi Annan called it ''a remarkable convergence of views.'' When about 150 government leaders representing a large majority of the world's nations ended their first no-frills working summit on Friday night, there was not much disagreement over the lopsided effects of the global economy. That was the easy part. Now, what to do about it.

The leaders made lofty pledges in a declaration. That and three days of speeches won't solve the problem, but behind the scenes, there was an innovation. Leaders broke into groups that mixed rich and poor, North and South, East and West, to thrash out ideas. The White House said there was even a moment when President Clinton and Fidel Castro exchanged a handshake and innocuous chitchat.

Prime Minister Goh Chok Tong of Singapore, who led one millennial roundtable, called it the organization's first ''interactive dialogue among leaders'' and suggested that the United Nations not wait a thousand years to do it again.
